source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk1

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk1
evidence_span: When radial hydrides are present in material with 200 to $3 0 0 \ \mathrm { p p m }$ hydrogen, a ductile-to-brittle transition occurs at $5 5 0 ~ \mathrm { K }$

evidence_span: Biaxial creep tests on cladding produce prism slip in recrystallized material, but basal slip in cold-worked, stress-relieved material

evidence_span: Biaxial creep tests on cladding produce prism slip in recrystallized material, but basal slip in cold-worked, stress-relieved material

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk1
evidence_span: Irradiation of this cladding decreased creep anisotropy due to activation of secondary slip systems

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk1
evidence_span: The fatigue limit was shown to decrease from $0 . 2 2 \%$ for unirradiated Zircaloy-2 cladding to $0 . 1 8 \%$ for material irradiated up to $6 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ $( E > 1 \ \mathrm { M e V } )$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk1
evidence_span: The fatigue limit was shown to decrease from $0 . 2 2 \%$ for unirradiated Zircaloy-2 cladding to $0 . 1 8 \%$ for material irradiated up to $6 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ $( E > 1 \ \mathrm { M e V } )$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Control of alloy elements to a narrow range within the specification limits for Zircaloy2 result in reduced sensitivity of uniform, ex-reactor corrosion on processing parameters

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The controlled composition material, low tin content and high iron and chromium content. exhibits better corrosion resistance than nominal composition Zircaloy-2
composition_raw: low tin content and high iron and chromium content

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Statistical analysis of the process variables in Zircaloy-2 cladding tube production shows that low tin content, texture characterized by high $f _ { r }$ values, stress relief annealing at final size, and the use of low intermediate annealing temperatures (especially late in the process) produce the best corrosion resistance to $7 7 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ steam autoclave tests
process_step: stress relief annealing at final size, low intermediate annealing temperatures

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The use of an accumulated annealing parameter to characterize the nodular corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-2 cladding tubes was questioned in another paper

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The percentage cold reduction performed during each pilger mill pass was found to be more significant than the annealing parameter
process_step: cold reduction during pilger mill pass

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The use of an electron microprobe with automated stage control was shown to be a useful means of relating the uniformity of alloy element concentration to $7 7 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ autoclave corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Tin was confirmed as the most important alloying element in determining uniform corrosion resistance during development of a new cladding alloy, Zr-1Sn-0.28Fe-0.16Cr-0.1Nb0.01Ni

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Another alloy development program concluded that the corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 could be improved by reducing tin content to $0 . 5 \%$ and adding a small amount of niobium to the alloy

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Additions of Mo and $\mathbf { V }$ can be used to improve the mechanical properties of this aloy

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: These additions increase intermetallic precipitate density, but not the precipitate size

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Other researchers saw little or no effect of iron, chromium, nickel, or oxygen content on uniform corrosion resistance of Zircaloys

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Improved corrosion resistance with reduced tin content was attributed to a decrease in stress within the oxide

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The dense barrier layer changes when the oxide thickness reached $3 \mu \mathrm { m }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The post-transition corrosion rate correlates with the properties of this barrier layer

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Fine, equiaxed monoclinic oxide, which forms under the influence of hydrogen, cracks easily at grain boundaries and results in nodular corrosion

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The use of Raman spectroscopy revealed the existence near the oxide-metal interface of tetragonal oxide which limits the corrosion kinetics prior to transition

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: At transition the tetragonal oxide decomposes to a porous monoclinic oxide in which grain boundary diffusion predominates

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Raman spectroscopy revealed the presence of tetragonal oxide on Zr-Sn-(Fe, Cr, or Ni) alloys in addition to the monoclinic oxide observed in binary $Z \mathbf { r } { - } \mathbf { S } \mathbf { n }$ alloys

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Oxides of these alloys were shown to have the characteristics of $n$ -type semiconductors by photo-electrochemical measurements

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The addition of Fe, Cr, and Ni to ${ \bf Z } { \bf r { - } } { \bf S } { \bf n }$ alloys increases the oxygen vacancy density in sub-stoichiometric oxide

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Atom probe measurements reveal the matrix of cladding to be fully depleted after only short time annealing

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The existence of a critical $\Sigma A$ value for obtaining good uniform corrosion resistance is not related to changes in the matrix composition

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Alloys exhibiting the highest electrical resistivity in the metal also exhibited the best corrosion resistance

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: The effect of beta quenching is to increase the solute concentration in the metal and thereby increase the electrical resistivity

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Zirconium intermetallic compounds were shown to be electrochemically noble to the matrix

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Heat flux was shown to have a greater influence on corrosion rate acceleration than the thermal gradient across the oxide film only

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: Precipitation of hydrides at the metal-oxide interface reduces the coherency between the barrier layer and the base metal

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk2
evidence_span: As a result, both the oxidation rate and the hydrogen uptake by the metal increase after hydride precipitation in the metal

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_003_chunk3
evidence_span: The in-reactor oxidation of zirconium alloys, the structural material in almost all water-cooled and water-moderated reactors, can be life-limiting

evidence_span: Due to the favorable neutron cross section, mechanical properties, and corrosion resistance of zirconium alloys

evidence_span: the compositions of the initial alloys (i.e. the Zircaloys) were selected primarily based on their out-of-pile corrosion resistances

evidence_span: For early Pressurized-Water Reactors (PWRs) and Boiling Water Reactors (BWRs), the corrosion resistances have been quite adequate for design exposures
